intro.p: Visual Albums such as Kanye West’s Runway and the Beatles’ A Hard Day Night have put the music industry on it’s head. Since A Hard Day Night, the genre of Visual Albums developed and chqangedchanged through the years.As a genre, Visual Albums bring the writer closer to the reader in a way that exceeds other genres such as: music videos and songs. This genre utilizes it’sits uptakes, scenes, and situations to bring the two togetherI'm a little unclear here what the "two" is referring to. Music videos and songs? I'm also unsure how a particular text "utilizes" its scenes and situations, but hopefully you'll elaborate on that in the essay itself.

body.bodyPara: The values that this genre focuses on is to be the best in your field, as most artists release a song by itself, others go the extra mile by making a music video, and only a select few go even further and release a visual album. The scene and situation help us understand the story more through the genre that is being used. Using Beyoncé’s Lemonade as a well established scene from this genreI think you are minunderstanding the relationship between scene, situation and genre. See our early discussions and vocab list for clarification; my understanding is that situations exist within scenes, and situations are coordinated through genres--meaning a single text (i.e. Lemonade) isn't an example of a scene, but rather operates in a particular scene or scenes (the music industry, US popular culture, media, etc.), and responds to a particular recurrent situation within that scene., you can see the impact of her choosing visual albums as her platform.platform for what? what is the recurrent situation that this genre responds to within the scene? This genre helped Beyoncé reach out to her fans in a much more direct way by being very personal and in touch with the current times, which created a long discussion about some of the situations that were exposed in Lemonade, such as the very famous lyrics from the song Sorry “He only want me when I'm not there. He better call Becky with the good hair”. it seems to me that the discussion following the release of the visual album should be considered uptake rather than situation

Singers, artists, poets, and public speakers are not the only people who use this genre. There are also the directors and musical engineers who in charge of development and upgrading the elements within the genre. Going back to the previously mentioned situation, Lemonade featured the Somali-English poet Warsaw Shire in one of it’s chapters. Warsaw Shire uses the genre of Visual Albums to input her own personal situation which many people including Beyoncé related to, this demonstrates how she uses her own uptake of combining her poetry with the sub-genre of video.I think you're close to an interesting claim here, but again, I am confused how you are using our key vocabulary. What do you mean by uptake here? It may help to define terms more thoroughly in your essay People who do not have the talent or ideas to make a visual albums can not use this genre, however they make up a vast majority of readers of this genre.okay, but didn't you just say that a poet (someone who doesn't have the 'skills' to make a visual album i.e. probably can't sing/make music) participated. What evidence do you have for this claim?

Visual Albums invite many different uptakes that help the artist connect to as many people as possible. Uptakes in visual albums work as a medium for the writers to express their feelings in a wide range of oppertunities. These uptakes include the use of song and video, the use of old tribal dances in a contemporary music video, and the combination of poetry and speech with visuals.Okay, I'm trying to follow here, but you aren't providing any concrete evidence for this claim. The use of song and video together encompasses the genres of visual albums and music videos, as both are very similar concepts. Using this uptakeyou seem to be using this term to describe a lot of different things in the same paragraph, which is a bit hard to follow. offers a more in-depth story that the artist is trying to convey to the audience.why is this situation? Going back to Lemonade, Beyoncé uses visuals eluding to feelings of sadness and betrayal in the song Pray You Catch Me to convey her situation of being cheated on. The use of old tribal dances and contemporary music as an uptake gives the artist a way to demonstrate theirare you still specifically talking about Lemonade here? background and culture to a much bigger platform of readers. Beyoncé mixes the two together in the song Sorry by performing an old tribal dance called The Sacred Art of Ori, which showed her own culture and backgrounduse q for quotes and citation for the in-text citation. Last but not least, the use of spoken word and visuals gives a deeper understanding of what the speaker is trying to convey, or the artists’ interpretation of the different speakers they use.how is this situation? Beyoncé uses an excerpt from a speech given by Malcolm X in May 22, 1962 with visuals of various black women to emphasize the importance of the speech to the black community and especially to black women. why do you need a citation here? Also, where is the analysis; I don't understand how the inclusion of the speech is evidence of your claim that spoken word and visuals combine to give the audience a "deeper understanding" or "the artist's interpretation"

The roles of the writer and reader are very important in the success of this genre. The writer’s main role is to create something that will have a long lasting impact on the readers, the longer the impact the more successful the artist becomes. Other roles that the writer has to keep in mind is making an album that talks about the current social issues that are plaguing the writers’ life.this paragraph is very vague; stay with specifics about Lemonade, especially in a paper this short Beyoncé succeeded in fulfilling the roles twice, once in 2013 with the album BEYONCÉ and the next in 2016 with Lemonade. Our roles as readers however is to appreciate the time and effort taken by the writer to complete their project and to express our views of what was read, weather it was negative or positive.very vague and not making a claim about the specific text you are looking at

p.argument: Visual Albums as a genre bringsbring the writer closer to the reader in a way that exceeds other genres such as: music videos and songs. This genre utilizes it’sits uptakes, scenes, and situations to bring the two together. The values that this genre articulates encourage the writers to connect to their readers. The writers’ exclusivity and roles also put an emphasis on trying to relate to the majority and connect with them as well.

report.p: Good, catchy start to the introduction to keep the reader engaged and interested in the analysis. It’s good that you provided some background to the topic. Slightly awkward layout of the introduction, should all be in one paragraph. Good referencing from a particular song and video, shows that you have knowledge in the topic. How does Beyoncé making a visual album help her connect with her fans in a more direct way? Explain (para 2 last sentence). Consider expanding on how the scene and situation helps us understand the story more through the genre that is being used. Maybe define uptake in terms of your genre and in light of your analysis for us to understand the concept better rather than its generic meaning. Valid use of genre in most of the essay. Would be a good idea if you briefly describe a music video so that the reader doesn’t have to watch it to understand what you mean by feelings of sadness and betrayal. I like how you mentioned that Beyoncé used old tribal dances and contemporary music as an uptake and explained it. Except for the introduction, I like how you’ve structured your paragraphs with new ideas/ topics in each paragraph. Good job in linking your new ideas to ideas mentioned previously. Valid points made throughout the essay. I like how you elaborated on the importance of the roles of both the reader and the writer. Good understanding of the deeper implications of her Visual Albums and song lyrics. Would be a good idea to replace “uses an excerpt from” to “alludes to” in the fourth paragraph. Another note, “eluding to a feelings” delete the “a”. Overall I enjoyed the essay as it is about a contemporary artist and her personal and profession life. Good use of literary terms and key terms such as genre and uptake (as discussed during class). Would like it if you considered changing the points mentioned above. .

So I find this an interesting topic, but I often struggled to follow your claims in the essay. The biggest issue, in my opinion, is your use of the key vocabulary words of genre analysis. See my in-text comments above for examples and specifics, but I am not sure how you are using scene, situation, and uptake in your essay. As your reviewer mentioned, it might be a good idea to define these with respect to your genre. I think you actually misuse the term "scene" and the term "situation" throughout the essay. See lengthy comment above on the relation between scene, situation, and genre as articulated in the class and through the readings. You did make some interesting claims, but struggled to connect specific evidence to those claims with sustained analysis. If you revise, one route you might take is to reduce the number of claims you make and spend more time elaborating your strongest claims. I think the idea of uptake is a powerful one here--Beyonce's uptake of previous genres to create a hybrid genre; the public's uptake of certain lyrics/images in the visual album and how those circulate in the media, etc. etc. You could easily write this paper on that. Lastly, you often make very generalized claims that lack evidence at all. For example, the writer's role is to make an impact on readers. What does this mean? All writers? Musical artists? Beyonce? It is just too vague an assertion to really prove in any meaningful way.
I'm happy to talk more about the essay and help you revise if you choose to do so.

. A successful genre analysis should:
Address one (or more) of the questions posed on the prompt: I see that you tried to address questions, but I struggle to follow how you address them and why
Contain a clearly stated main argument: there is an argument, though it could be made much more specific and more clearly related to the text at hand
Emphasize evidence in support of claims (textual evidence or otherwise): lacks analysis linking evidence to claims
Use a few of the terms from the vocabulary list: see above discussions of use of scene, situation, and uptake
Provide an overview of genre broadly (beyond an individual text): does mention the beatles, but no sense of the genre as a response to a recurrent situation within a specific scene
Be detailed and focused: see comments above
Contain citations (in-text and works cited): lacks in-text citations (could be misunderstanding of the XML
Be structured as an essay: good
